TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-silty, carbonatic, isohyperthermic Thapto-Histic Fluvaquents

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Keywest marl from a tidal area dominated by black and white mangroves.
A--0 to 9 inches; light gray (10YR 7/1) marl (silt loam); weak coarse platy structure parting to weak fine granular; very friable; common medium roots; common fine and very fine pores; 5 percent by volume of shell fragments; strongly effervescent; mildly alkaline; abrupt smooth boundary (4 to 20 inches thick).
Oa--9 to 15 inches; dark brown (7.5YR 3/2) muck (rubbed and unrubbed); about 30 percent unrubbed fiber content and less than 5 percent rubbed; 30 percent by volume of live roots; massive; very friable; neutral in calcium chloride; abrupt smooth boundary (4 to 15 inches thick).
A/Oa--15 to 27 inches; gray and brown mucky marl which is 70 percent by volume of light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) marl and 30 percent by volume of dark brown (10YR 4/3) muck; massive; very friable; 3 percent by volume of shell fragments; neutral in calcium chloride and moderately alkaline in water; clear smooth boundary (8 to 25 inches thick).
Cg--27 to 65 inches; light gray (10YR 7/1) marl (silt loam); massive; friable; few fine roots; few fine pores; thin strata of dominantly sand size shells; moderately alkaline; abrupt smooth boundary.
2R--65 inches; soft to hard but rippable oolitic limestone.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Monroe County, Florida; Boot Key; 1.4 miles southeast of U. S. Hwy 1 on County Road 931 and 50 feet northwest of road; SE 1/4, SE 1/4, SW 1/4, Sec. 16. T. 66 S., R. 32 E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Depth to bedrock is 40 to 90 inches.  Reaction ranges from neutral to moderately alkaline.  The soil has  more than 90 percent calcium carbonate in the marl layers.  The soil has less than 10 percent by volume of gravel size fragments.
The A horizon has hue of 10YR or 2.5Y, value of 4 to 8, and chroma of 1 or 2.  Where value is 4 or 5, chroma is 1.  Texture is marl with a noncarbonate free texture of silt or silt loam.
The Oa horizon has hue of 5YR to 10YR, value of 3 or 4, and chroma of 2 to 4.  Fiber content is 20 to 50 percent unrubbed and less than 10 percent rubbed.  Reaction is slightly acid to mildly alkaline in calcium chloride.
The A/Oa horizon is neutral to moderately alkaline. It is 60 to 70 percent marl(A) and 30 to 40 percent muck(Oa).  The A portion has the same ranges of color and texture as the A horizon.  The Oa portion has the same ranges of color and texture as the Oa horizon.
The Cg horizon has hue of 10YR or 2.5Y, value of 6 to 8, and chroma of 1 or 2.  Texture is marl with a non-carbonate free texture of silt or silt loam.  In some pedons, the Cg horizon is stratified marl and sand size shell fragment.
The 2R horizon is soft to hard but rippable coral or oolitic limestone.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the  Cudjoe, Lignumvitae, and Saddlebunch series in similar families and the Biscayne, Perrine, and Pennsuco series in hyperthermic families.  Cudjoe, Lignumvitae, and Saddlebunch soils have bedrock within 40 inches of the surface.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Keywest soils are on tidal mangrove swamps.  Elevations are dominantly at 1929 NGVD. Keywest soils are subject to flooding from tides. The mean annual temperature ranges from 75 to 78 degrees F. and the mean annual precipitation ranges from 40 to 50 inches.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content:
GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the well drained
mineral Keyvaca and Pennkamp soils and the moderately well drained organic Matecumbe and the somewhat poorly drained marly Saddlebunch soils on higher landforms; the poorly drained marly Cudjoe and Lignumvitae soils on similar landforms; and the very poorly drained organic Islamorada, Keylargo, and Tavernier soils on lower landforms.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  These soils are poorly drained with a high water table of 0 to 6 inches during wet periods of most years.  Permeability is moderate to moderately rapid.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Most areas of the soil are used as wildlife habitat.  The dominate native vegetation is black mangroves.  Red mangroves, white mangroves, saltwort, and glasswort are also common.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Keywest soils are of small known extent on the Florida Keys.  These soils may occur on other tropical islands.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Auburn, Alabama

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Monroe County, Florida, 1989.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
